questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of photophobia and pruritus on the periocular area of the right eye. He also had crusts over the eyelashes of the right eye that morning. The boy has a history of asthma and atopic dermatitis. His medications include inhaled steroids and salbutamol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows conjunctival injection and redness of the affected eye with watery discharge. There are multiple vesicles with an erythematous base located on the upper and lower eyelids. Visual acuity test shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum virus is a cause of chronic follicular conjunctivitis, a condition that usually manifests with chronic unilateral ocular irritation and mucoid discharge. The virus causes typical umbilicated nodules which can be found on the lid margin and possibly on other areas of the skin. The patient, in this case, presents with acute conjunctivitis and a rash characteristic of a different disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia trachomatis is the leading cause of neonatal conjunctivitis (or ophthalmia neonatorum). Infection is usually caused by exposure to contaminated maternal discharge, typically during birth, and patients present with mucopurulent discharge. Infection of older patients leads to granular conjunctivitis (trachoma) and can cause blindness. Common findings include follicles and papillae on the conjunctiva as well as scarring and corneal damage later in the course of the disease. These features are inconsistent with this patient's watery discharge and a periorbital rash.

C) INCORRECT:

Adenoviruses are the most common cause of viral (nonpurulent) conjunctivitis. The disease is highly contagious and commonly occurs in small outbreaks. Typical symptoms include itching, serous discharge, severe foreign body sensation, and conjunctival hyperemia, as mentioned in this case. However, adenovirus conjunctivitis typically affects both eyes, either simultaneously or in sequence. Most importantly, although it often presents with signs of systemic infection, such as pharyngitis, fever, and lymphadenopathy, it is not associated with a vesicular rash.

D) INCORRECT:

Enterovirus 70 is a picornavirus that causes acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. Patients present with a sudden onset of pain, periorbital swelling, subconjunctival hemorrhages, and conjunctival injection. In most cases, the infection involves both eyes. Though the patient, in this case, presents with conjunctival injection, a periocular rash is characteristic of a different disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute infection with varicella-zoster virus sometimes causes conjunctivitis. Patients are usually children and present with additional symptoms such as fever and a generalized vesiculopustular rash. The conjunctiva can also be affected in reactivation of the latent virus in the trigeminal ganglion (herpes zoster ophthalmicus). These patients are often older or immunosuppressed and present with a headache, fever, and a vesicular rash along the trigeminal dermatome. None of these features are present in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Bacterial conjunctivitis is the most common form of infectious conjunctivitis in children. Common pathogens include Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis. Infection usually manifests as purulent conjunctivitis with thick yellow, white, or green discharge, which is inconsistent with this patient's nonpurulent conjunctivitis and watery discharge.

G) CORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) can cause nonpurulent conjunctivitis, which manifests with photophobia, pruritus on the periocular area, crusts over the eyelashes, conjunctival injection, redness, and watery discharge from the eye. HSV-1 conjunctivitis is more common in children and adults, while HSV-2 often affects neonates. HSV conjunctivitis is usually unilateral and often manifests with a vesicular rash and corneal involvement (e.g., dendritic keratitis). Additionally, patients with a history of atopic dermatitis are particularly susceptible to HSV conjunctivitis.

HSV conjunctivitis is usually self-limited and resolves within 2 weeks, although neonatal forms can be fatal. The gold standard for diagnosis of HSV conjunctivitis is cell culture. However, typical cases in neonates or immunosuppressed patients should be treated without laboratory confirmation, as testing may delay treatment. In adults, treatment is only indicated in corneal involvement. Therapy usually consists of topical, oral, and/or IV acyclovir, depending on the severity of the disease, the age of the patient, and underlying conditions (e.g., immunosuppression).
Image Description:

Left eye

The conjunctival blood vessels are dilated (injection). There is no purulent discharge.

This finding is consistent with viral conjunctivitis.

H) INCORRECT:

Allergic conjunctivitis manifests with itchiness, chemosis (swelling of the conjunctiva), and serous secretion. Despite its association with atopic conditions such as asthma and atopic dermatitis, symptoms of allergic conjunctivitis are usually milder than those of infectious conjunctivitis and do not include a vesicular rash.
questions.hint: What infection associated with multiple vesicles are patients with atopic dermatitis prone to?

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 2-week history of watery discharge from her right eye. She and her parents have immigrated from Sudan one month ago. Her immunization status is unknown. She is at the 25th percentile for weight and the 50th percentile for height. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 18/min. Examination of the right eye shows matting of the eyelashes. Everting the right eyelid shows hyperemia, follicles, and papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva. Slit-lamp examination of the right eye shows follicles in the limbic region and the bulbar conjunctiva. There is corneal haziness with neovascularization at the 12 o'clock position. Examination of the left eye is unremarkable. Direct ophthalmoscopy of both eyes shows no abnormalities. Right preauricular lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vernal conjunctivitis is IgE-mediated allergic conjunctivitis that is bilateral, seasonal, and self-limiting. It is prevalent among male individuals between the age of 4 and 20 years and manifests with severe itching with reflex lacrimation. However, this patient is a girl with unilateral watery discharge. Additionally, examination of a patient with vernal conjunctivitis would show giant cobblestone papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctivae.

B) INCORRECT:

Adenoviral conjunctivitis is the most common cause of viral conjunctivitis in children and adults. It has an acute onset and usually affects one eye but can spread to the other eye within a few days. It also manifests with marked foreign body sensation, photophobia, lacrimation, and follicular conjunctivitis. Adenoviral conjunctivitis does not manifest with papillae or corneal haziness with neovascularization, however, meaning it is an unlikely diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Giant papillary conjunctivitis is a form of allergic conjunctivitis that commonly manifests with a foreign body sensation, itching, and mild mucoid discharge in patients who wear contact lenses or ocular prostheses. Examination shows giant papillae (> 1 mm), which is the hallmark of this disease. This 5-year-old girl does not wear contact lenses and does not have giant papillae on physical examination. Moreover, the follicles and the corneal haziness with neovascularization make giant papillary conjunctivitis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with angular conjunctivitis present with itching, redness, conjunctival hyperemia, and foamy discharge at the angles of the eye rather than the watery discharge seen in this patient. Examination showing papillae, follicles, and corneal neovascularization would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

The most characteristic clinical feature of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is subconjunctival hemorrhage, which is not present in this patient. The fact that it manifests as bilateral conjunctivitis with conjunctival hyperemia and chemosis makes it an even less likely diagnosis in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Neisserial conjunctivitis predominantly affects neonates and sexually active adults. It is acute in nature and manifests as severe, bilateral conjunctivitis with profuse mucopurulent discharge. It is also associated with arthritis and urethritis but not neovascularization of the cornea. Although it can also manifest with preauricular lymphadenopathy, this 5-year-old girl's unilateral conjunctivitis is not consistent with neisserial conjunctivitis

G) INCORRECT:

Acute herpetic conjunctivitis is typically caused by HSV type 1 and commonly affects small children and adults. Patients present with acute onset unilateral conjunctivitis with serous discharge. Examination typically shows follicular conjunctivitis and sometimes vesicular lesions around the eye and face, neither of which are seen in this patient. If it involves the cornea, it causes dendritic or punctate ulcers rather than corneal haziness with neovascularization.

H) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is consistent with trachoma, which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes A–C. While it is rare in North America, it constitutes a major public health concern in rural areas of developing countries, particularly in Africa, Asia, and the Middle East. Trachoma initially manifests as follicular conjunctivitis and then progresses to a mixed papillary and follicular conjunctivitis, as seen in this case. The patient's corneal haziness with neovascularization is called pannus and is a classic presentation of active trachoma.

See “Overview of conjunctivitis subtypes in children and adults” table.
Image Description:

Clinical features of trachoma in a child

A: Conjunctival follicles, consisting of whitish hyperplastic lymphatic tissue, on the ectropionized
upper eyelid

B: Conjunctival scarring of the ectropionized upper eyelid

C: The upper eyelid is folded inwards (entropion) and the eyelashes are growing inwards towards the cornea (trichiasis)

D: Corneal opacification due to scarring (manifests as loss of vision)

These findings are consistent with the active and cicatricial phase of C. trachomatis infection.
questions.hint: Histopathological examination of conjunctival scrapings from this patient's right eye would likely show intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies and large multinucleated cells.

questions.text: Two days after delivery, a newborn is brought to the physician because of a red, irritated eye with yellow discharge. She was born via vaginal delivery at 39 weeks' gestation to a 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. The mother had an unmedicated delivery at home; the patient did not receive any routine postpartum medications. The mother had not seen her gynecologist since her first prenatal visit. The newborn's temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 42/min, and blood pressure is 73/53 mm Hg. Ophthalmic examination shows eyelid edema, conjunctival injection, and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge from the right eye. There is no corneal ulceration or evidence of keratitis. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?

choices.text: Oral erythromycin administered to the infant
IV ceftriaxone administered to the infant
Topical erythromycin administered to the infant
Oral doxycycline administered to the mother
Oral amoxicillin administered to the mother

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral erythromycin is the first-line treatment for chlamydial neonatal conjunctivitis, which typically occurs 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with mild eyelid swelling and watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge. This patient's presentation is consistent with NGC, for which oral erythromycin is not indicated as either prophylaxis or treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous or intramuscular ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice in infants with NGC. However, ceftriaxone is not used for NGC prophylaxis.

C) CORRECT:

Topical erythromycin ointment should be applied within 1 hour of birth to prevent NGC. In most states in the US, prophylaxis against NGC is required by law. If left untreated, NGC may result in corneal scarring and blindness. After confirming NGC (using culture and Gram stain or PCR), systemic treatment with either an IV or IM third-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone) is indicated. In addition, the eyes should be flushed with saline until the discharge clears.
Image Description:

The eyelids are swollen, with purulent exudate forming crusts around them. Below the crusts there may be a large reservoir of pus. Special care should be taken and safety goggles should be worn when examining the eyes.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline may be administered to treat mothers of newborns who have newborn conjunctivitis due to an infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. However, administration of oral doxycycline (as a prophylactic measure) in pregnant women is contraindicated because it may lead to bone damage and deposits in teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) in the offspring.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin can be used to treat infection with Chlamydia trachomatis in pregnant women and, therefore, help prevent chlamydial neonatal conjunctivitis (CNC). However, CNC typically occurs 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with mild eyelid swelling and watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge. This patient's presentation is more consistent with NGC. Amoxicillin is not the first-line treatment for infection with Neisseria gonorrhea and, therefore, would have not prevented this newborn's NGC.
questions.hint: This patient presents with conjunctival injection and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge 2 days after birth, all of which are consistent with neonatal gonococcal conjunctivitis (NGC). NGC is typically caused by ophthalmic colonization of the newborn's conjunctiva during delivery from mothers with Neisseria gonorrhea infection.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of redness, foreign body sensation, and discharge in both eyes. She reports that her eyes feel “stuck together” and form yellow crusts every morning. She has a 3-year history of nasal allergies. Family history is remarkable for allergic rhinitis in her sister. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmic examination shows edema of both eyelids, bilateral conjunctival injection, and a thin purulent discharge. Examination of the cornea, anterior chamber, and fundus is unremarkable. The remainder of the examination, including a visual acuity test, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical ketorolac, an NSAID, is used to reduce the pain, inflammation, and swelling seen in allergic conjunctivitis, which manifests with bilateral redness, foreign body sensation, and discharge of eyes, as seen in this patient. This patient's personal and family history of allergies is also a risk factor for the development of allergic conjunctivitis. However, the discharge in this patient is purulent instead of watery/mucoid; and itching and follicles on the tarsal conjunctiva, both characteristic features of allergic conjunctivitis, are not seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Right eye of an older adult

Conjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.

This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisolone acetate drops) may be used for the treatment of refractory allergic conjunctivitis (e.g., vernal keratoconjunctivitis), which manifests with bilateral redness, foreign body sensation, and discharge of eyes, as seen in this patient. This patient's personal and family history of allergies is also a risk factor for allergic conjunctivitis. However, the discharge in this patient is purulent instead of watery/mucoid, and itching and follicles on the tarsal conjunctiva, both characteristic features of allergic conjunctivitis, are not seen in this patient.

Topical glucocorticoids should not be used for conjunctivitis unless an infectious etiology is ruled out, as they can lead to worsening of the infection and sight-threatening complications such as keratitis and corneal perforation.
Image Description:

Ectropionized upper right eyelid of a young boy

Cobblestone-like lesions, called “giant papillae” (green outline), are visible on the tarsal conjunctive of the upper eyelid.

This finding is consistent with vernal keratoconjunctivitis, a severe form of allergic inflammation in the eye. It may lead to further complications, including corneal ulcer.

C) CORRECT:

The most common organism causing bacterial conjunctivitis in adults is Staphylococcus aureus, followed by Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae. While most cases of bacterial conjunctivitis are self-limited, the use of topical antibiotics speeds up recovery and may reduce the risk of transmission. There is no superior antibiotic regimen; selection should be based on cost, availability, and local resistance data. Empiric treatment should be with a topical broad-spectrum antibiotic, such as erythromycin or a combination of trimethoprim/polymyxin B.
Image Description:

Left eye

There is massive conjunctival injection (hyperemia) and purulent discharge, especially visible in the medial corner of the eye and the margin of the lower lid.

This is the characteristic appearance of bacterial conjunctivitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical fluoroquinolones like ciprofloxacin are usually not preferred for empiric treatment of bacterial conjunctivitis because of the concerns surrounding increasing bacterial drug resistance. The only exception is contact lens wearers since the most common causative organism of bacterial conjunctivitis in this group of patients is Pseudomonas aeruginosa, against which fluoroquinolones are effective. Pseudomonas conjunctivitis is often more fulminant and can rapidly lead to sight-threatening keratitis and corneal perforation. As this patient does not wear contact lenses and her presentation is not as severe, another treatment option is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Artificial tears (e.g., carboxymethyl cellulose) can be used for lubrication in patients with dry eye disease (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) as well as in contact lens wearers. Dry eye disease manifests with a foreign body sensation in the eye, along with itching and redness, but it is not accompanied by purulent discharge. While artificial tears may be used in bacterial conjunctivitis for symptomatic relief, a different treatment is required to target this patient's infection.

F) INCORRECT:

Oral azithromycin is the treatment of choice for patients with inclusion conjunctivitis, which is caused by infection with Chlamydia trachomatis (types D–K) and frequently occurs in combination with chlamydial genitourinary infections. Although this patient is at risk of developing a chlamydial infection because of the inconsistent use of condoms with more than one sexual partner and presents with bilateral conjunctival injection and purulent discharge, both of which are characteristic of inclusion conjunctivitis, the absence of conjunctival follicles, and a cobblestone appearance of the palpebral conjunctiva makes this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

The tarsal conjunctiva appears edematous with developing follicles (examples indicated by green overlay).

These findings are consistent with inclusion conjunctivitis due to Chlamydia trachomatis infection.
questions.hint: This patient's eyelid edema, conjunctival injection, and yellow purulent discharge are suggestive of acute bacterial conjunctivitis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of itchy, watery eyes for the past week. He has also been sneezing multiple times a day during this period. He had a similar episode 1 year ago in spring. He has iron deficiency anemia and ankylosing spondylitis. Current medications include ferrous sulfate, artificial tear drops, and indomethacin. He works as an elementary school teacher. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral conjunctival injection with watery discharge. The pupils are 3 mm, equal, and reactive to light. Visual acuity test and slit-lamp examination show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythromycin ointment may be administered in the case of bacterial conjunctivitis, which is typically unilateral and often leads to purulent discharge. Although this patient presents with conjunctivitis, his conjunctivitis is bilateral and is associated with itching and watery discharge. Moreover, it occurs during specific times of the year, which makes a bacterial infection unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Ganciclovir eye drops may be used to treat patients with herpes simplex conjunctivitis, which typically present with unilateral conjunctival injections, chemosis, and tearing. Concurrent vesicular blepharitis with eyelid edema is common. This patient has bilateral conjunctivitis and no evidence of eyelid involvement, making herpes simplex conjunctivitis an unlikely diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Second-generation antihistamines such as ketotifen can be used in the treatment of SAC. Patients should also try to avoid irritating agents (e.g., allergens, contact lenses) if possible. The use of cold compresses, artificial tears, and local NSAIDs (e.g., ketorolac) can provide additional symptomatic relief for these patients.
Image Description:

Right eye of an older adult

Conjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.

This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Warm compresses may be used to treat hordeolum, which typically manifests with a painful, erythematous, pus-filled tender nodule that can perforate, releasing purulent discharge. However, this patient presents with signs and symptoms that are consistent with SAC, for which cold rather than warm compresses are usually recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

Low-dose glucocorticoids such as fluorometholone are used as second-line treatment for SAC. Because glucocorticoids are associated with numerous ophthalmologic side effects (e.g., intraocular pressure elevation, cataract formation), they are only indicated if patients do not respond to first-line treatment.

Glucocorticoids are also used for the treatment of uveitis, which is a common finding in patients with systemic inflammatory conditions, including ankylosing spondylitis. However, this patient's normal slit-lamp examination findings make uveitis highly unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Latanoprost eye drops are used to treat elevated intraocular pressure in chronic glaucoma, which typically affects older individuals and manifests with few, often nonspecific symptoms such as headache, burning, reddening of the eye, and possibly halos. Although this patient presents with reddening of the eyes, he is only 35 years of age and his recurrent symptoms of sneezing and bilateral itchy and watery conjunctivitis are more consistent with SAC.
questions.hint: This patient's recurrent symptoms of sneezing and bilateral itchy, watery conjunctivitis that worsen around springtime are suggestive of seasonal allergic conjunctivitis (SAC).

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 4-day history of irritation and redness in both eyes. Her symptoms initially started in the left eye and progressed to involve both eyes within 24 hours. She presents with profuse tearing and reports that her eyes are sticky and difficult to open in the morning. She was diagnosed with asthma 2 years ago and has been admitted to the hospital for acute exacerbations three times since then. Current medications include inhaled beclomethasone, inhaled albuterol, and montelukast. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). Physical examination reveals a tender left preauricular lymph node. There is chemosis and diffuse erythema of the bulbar conjunctiva bilaterally with watery discharge. Slit-lamp examination shows a follicular reaction in both palpebral conjunctivae and diffuse, fine epithelial keratitis of both corneas. Corneal sensation is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Supportive therapy with artificial tears and cold compresses is the most appropriate treatment for uncomplicated epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, a self-limiting adenovirus infection that typically resolves completely within one week. Due to the highly contagious nature of this adenovirus infection, prevention is critical, especially in healthcare settings.

See “Overview of conjunctivitis subtypes in children and adults” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral cetirizine is used to treat symptoms of allergic rhinitis. The ocular manifestations of allergic rhinitis may also include conjunctival erythema with watery discharge, but almost always include immediate bilateral involvement and prominent itchiness, none of which is seen in this patient. Moreover, lymphadenopathy is not a feature of allergic rhinitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical prednisolone acetate is used to minimize ocular inflammation in cases of severe allergic conjunctivitis, autoimmune conditions such as uveitis or severe bacterial keratitis, and after ophthalmic surgery. Steroids are not indicated for viral infections such as epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral acyclovir is the first-line treatment for herpes simplex keratitis, which usually manifests with unilateral conjunctivitis accompanied by a foreign body sensation. The classic finding on ocular examination is linearly branching corneal ulcers (dendritic ulcers). This patient has bilateral conjunctivitis with watery discharge, making herpes simplex infection unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Natamycin is an appropriate treatment for fungal eye infections, which are very rare. The major risk factor for development of these infections is a traumatic eye injury with fungal contamination. Symptoms besides erythema include intense pain, photophobia, and purulent drainage. Since this patient does not have severe pain or photophobia and has no history of eye injury, fungal infection is highly unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Topical moxifloxacin is reserved for use in moderate to severe bacterial conjunctivitis, which manifests with erythematous conjunctiva, purulent discharge, upper lid papillae on slit-lamp examination, and possibly fever and lymphadenopathy. This patient has copious watery discharge and follicles on slit-lamp examination, meaning bacterial conjunctivitis is unlikely.

G) INCORRECT:

Topical erythromycin is an appropriate treatment for mild bacterial conjunctivitis, which manifests with erythematous conjunctiva, purulent discharge, and upper lid papillae on slit-lamp examination. This patient has copious watery ocular discharge, lymphadenopathy, and follicles on slit-lamp examination, all of which make mild bacterial conjunctivitis unlikely.
questions.hint: Redness and profuse watery discharge which start in one eye and rapidly spread to the other, preauricular lymphadenopathy, low-grade fever, and signs of corneal inflammation are consistent with epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of red, itchy, tearing eyes. He says that the left eye feels “swollen,” but it does not hurt and he can still see everything clearly. He spent the last couple of days at his cousin's house in the countryside but had to return home today as his cousin developed an upper respiratory tract infection. The patient has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Family history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis in his mother. Immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Ophthalmic examination shows bilateral conjunctival injection with watery discharge and chemosis. There is also bilateral eyelid edema and a 2-mm long abrasion on his left upper eyelid. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. Fundoscopic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS) can cause bilateral conjunctival injection. However, KCS does not affect the eyelids and is a subacute or chronic condition, not an acute one. Moreover, KCS typically results in dry eyes (rather than excessive tearing) and blurred vision (due to corneal involvement).

B) CORRECT:

Allergic conjunctivitis (AC) typically manifests with bilateral ocular itching, redness, and scant watery discharge, most commonly in young adults. AC is a hypersensitivity reaction against specific allergens (e.g., cat dander, pollen), to which this patient was likely exposed to in the countryside. Examination findings include diffuse conjunctival injection, chemosis, and eyelid edema. Additionally, eversion of the eyelid may show conjunctival papillae. Management of AC includes allergen avoidance, cold compresses, artificial tears, and topical pharmacotherapy (e.g., antihistamines). Systemic pharmacotherapy can be considered if nonocular symptoms are present.

See “Overview of conjunctivitis subtypes in children and adults” table.
Image Description:

Right eye of an older adult

Conjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.

This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Bacterial conjunctivitis typically manifests with unilateral or bilateral diffuse conjunctival injection and thick, purulent discharge. Patients don't typically present with significant itching. Additionally, patients often present with significant eyelid erythema and pain, none of which is seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Although episcleritis can manifest with the acute onset of bilateral ocular redness, tearing, and intact vision, eyelid edema is not consistent with this condition. Furthermore, in affected patients, hyperemia is localized to the globe and the palpebral conjunctiva appears normal; episcleral injection, not conjunctival injection, would be present.

In a minority of cases, episcleritis may be associated with underlying systemic illnesses such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which this patient has a family history. However, he has no other features of RA.

E) INCORRECT:

Viral conjunctivitis typically manifests with conjunctival injection and watery discharge. However, patients are unlikely to present with significant itching or eyelid edema. Although viral conjunctivitis can affect both eyes, it usually begins unilaterally. Additionally, patients often present with systemic and/or nasopharyngeal signs of viral infection (e.g., lymphadenopathy, pharyngitis).

F) INCORRECT:

Exacerbations of blepharitis can cause acute-onset bilateral eyelid swelling, itchiness, and tearing. However, blepharitis primarily manifests with erythema or adherent material (e.g., collarettes, crusty scaly plaques) at the lid margins. The absence of these findings and the presence of conjunctival injection and chemosis make a different diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: Individuals with this condition often have concomitant rhinitis.

questions.text: A 15-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician for evaluation of red eyes with discharge for 3 days. She was born at 37 weeks' gestation to a 26-year-old woman. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother received irregular prenatal care during the 3rd trimester of pregnancy. Examination of the newborn shows watery discharge in both eyes and mild eyelid swelling. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Silver nitrate exposure can lead to chemical conjunctivitis, which usually manifests in the 1st day of life with mild watery discharge and conjunctival injections. Discharge and eyelid swelling was observed in this patient 12 days after delivery, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of bacterial conjunctivitis in adults and typically presents with unilateral conjunctival injection, chemosis, and thick purulent discharge. This patient has watery eye discharge. Moreover, Staphylococcus aureus is not a common cause of conjunctivitis in neonates.

C) CORRECT:

Chlamydial conjunctivitis, which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, typically manifests at 5–14 days after birth with watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge in addition to mild eyelid swelling, as seen in this patient. Oral erythromycin is the treatment for chlamydial conjunctivitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Gonococcal conjunctivitis, which is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, typically manifests 2–7 days after delivery with profuse, purulent, ocular discharge in addition to a pronounced eyelid swelling. This patient, meanwhile, has a mild eyelid swelling and watery discharge observed 12 days after delivery, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus 2 is a common cause of viral conjunctivitis in neonates. It typically manifests within the first 14 days of life with nonpurulent, ocular discharge, corneal ulceration, and periocular vesicles. This patient lacks corneal ulceration and periocular vesicles, which make this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: A gram stain of this patient's discharge would yield a negative result.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy has a 2-day history of red, itchy, tearing eyes. He does not have any pain and he can see clearly. He spent the last couple of days at his cousin's house in the countryside. Examination shows bilateral conjunctival injection with watery discharge and chemosis. There is also bilateral eyelid edema. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS) can cause bilateral conjunctival injection. However, KCS does not affect the eyelids and is a subacute or chronic condition, not an acute one. Moreover, KCS typically results in dry eyes (rather than excessive tearing) and blurred vision (due to corneal involvement).

B) CORRECT:

Allergic conjunctivitis (AC) typically manifests with bilateral ocular itching, redness, and scant watery discharge, most commonly in young adults. AC is a hypersensitivity reaction against specific allergens (e.g., cat dander, pollen), to which this patient was likely exposed to in the countryside. Examination findings include diffuse conjunctival injection, chemosis, and eyelid edema. Additionally, eversion of the eyelid may show conjunctival papillae. Management of AC includes allergen avoidance, cold compresses, artificial tears, and topical pharmacotherapy (e.g., antihistamines). Systemic pharmacotherapy can be considered if nonocular symptoms are present.

See “Overview of conjunctivitis subtypes in children and adults” table.

Key learning point: Allergic conjunctivitis presents with bilateral itchy, red eyes, watery discharge, chemosis, and eyelid edema, often triggered by environmental allergens.
Image Description:

Right eye of an older adult

Conjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.

This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Bacterial conjunctivitis typically manifests with unilateral or bilateral diffuse conjunctival injection and thick, purulent discharge. Patients don't typically present with significant itching. Additionally, patients often present with significant eyelid erythema and pain, none of which is seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Viral conjunctivitis typically manifests with conjunctival injection and watery discharge. However, patients are unlikely to present with significant itching or eyelid edema. Although viral conjunctivitis can affect both eyes, it usually begins unilaterally. Additionally, patients often present with systemic and/or nasopharyngeal signs of viral infection (e.g., lymphadenopathy, pharyngitis).

E) INCORRECT:

Exacerbations of blepharitis can cause acute-onset bilateral eyelid swelling, itchiness, and tearing. However, blepharitis primarily manifests with erythema or adherent material (e.g., collarettes, crusty scaly plaques) at the lid margins. The absence of these findings and the presence of conjunctival injection and chemosis make a different diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: Individuals with this condition often have concomitant rhinitis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-day history of redness, foreign body sensation, and discharge in both eyes. She reports that her eyes feel “stuck together” and form yellow crusts every morning. Ophthalmic examination shows edema of both eyelids, bilateral conjunctival injection, and a thin purulent discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical ketorolac, an NSAID, is used to reduce the pain, inflammation, and swelling seen in allergic conjunctivitis, which manifests with bilateral redness, foreign body sensation, and discharge of eyes, as seen in this patient. However, the discharge in this patient is purulent instead of watery/mucoid; and itching and follicles on the tarsal conjunctiva, both characteristic features of allergic conjunctivitis, are not seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Right eye of an older adult

Conjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.

This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisolone acetate drops) may be used for the treatment of refractory allergic conjunctivitis (e.g., vernal keratoconjunctivitis), which manifests with bilateral redness, foreign body sensation, and discharge of eyes, as seen in this patient. However, the discharge in this patient is purulent instead of watery/mucoid, and itching and follicles on the tarsal conjunctiva, both characteristic features of allergic conjunctivitis, are not seen in this patient.

Topical glucocorticoids should not be used for conjunctivitis unless an infectious etiology is ruled out, as they can lead to worsening of the infection and sight-threatening complications such as keratitis and corneal perforation.
Image Description:

Ectropionized upper right eyelid of a young boy

Cobblestone-like lesions, called “giant papillae” (green outline), are visible on the tarsal conjunctive of the upper eyelid.

This finding is consistent with vernal keratoconjunctivitis, a severe form of allergic inflammation in the eye. It may lead to further complications, including corneal ulcer.

C) CORRECT:

The most common organism causing bacterial conjunctivitis in adults is Staphylococcus aureus, followed by Streptococcal pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae. While most cases of bacterial conjunctivitis are self-limited, the use of topical antibiotics speeds up recovery and may reduce the risk of transmission. There is no superior antibiotic regimen and selection should be based on cost, availability, and local resistance data. Empiric treatment should be with a topical broad-spectrum antibiotic, such as erythromycin or a combination of trimethoprim/polymyxin B.
Image Description:

Left eye

There is massive conjunctival injection (hyperemia) and purulent discharge, especially visible in the medial corner of the eye and the margin of the lower lid.

This is the characteristic appearance of bacterial conjunctivitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical fluoroquinolones like ciprofloxacin are usually not preferred for empiric treatment of bacterial conjunctivitis because of the concerns surrounding increasing bacterial drug resistance. The only exception is contact lens wearers since the most common causative organism of bacterial conjunctivitis in this group of patients is Pseudomonas aeruginosa, against which fluoroquinolones are effective. Pseudomonas conjunctivitis is often more fulminant and can rapidly lead to sight-threatening keratitis and corneal perforation. As this patient does not wear contact lenses and her presentation is not as severe, another treatment option is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Artificial tears (e.g., carboxymethyl cellulose) can be used for lubrication in patients with dry eye disease (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) as well as in contact lens wearers. Dry eye disease manifests with a foreign body sensation in the eye, along with itching and redness, but it is not accompanied by purulent discharge. While artificial tears may be used in bacterial conjunctivitis for symptomatic relief, a different treatment is required to target this patient's infection.
questions.hint: This patient's eyelid edema, conjunctival injection, and yellow purulent discharge are suggestive of acute bacterial conjunctivitis.

questions.text: A 15-day-old female newborn is brought to the office for evaluation of red eyes with discharge for 3 days. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother received irregular prenatal care during the 3rd trimester of pregnancy. Examination of the newborn shows watery discharge in both eyes and mild eyelid swelling. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Silver nitrate exposure can lead to chemical conjunctivitis, which usually manifests in the 1st day of life with mild watery discharge and conjunctival injections. Discharge and eyelid swelling was observed in this patient 12 days after delivery, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of bacterial conjunctivitis in adults and typically presents with unilateral conjunctival injection, chemosis, and thick purulent discharge. This patient has watery eye discharge. Moreover, Staphylococcus aureus is not a common cause of conjunctivitis in neonates.

C) CORRECT:

Chlamydial conjunctivitis, which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, typically manifests at 5–14 days after birth with watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge in addition to mild eyelid swelling, as seen in this patient. Oral erythromycin is the treatment for chlamydial conjunctivitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Gonococcal conjunctivitis, which is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, typically manifests 2–7 days after delivery with profuse, purulent, ocular discharge in addition to a pronounced eyelid swelling. This patient, meanwhile, has a mild eyelid swelling and watery discharge observed 12 days after delivery, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus 2 is a common cause of viral conjunctivitis in neonates. It typically manifests within the first 14 days of life with nonpurulent, ocular discharge, corneal ulceration, and periocular vesicles. This patient lacks corneal ulceration and periocular vesicles, which make this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: A gram stain of this patient's discharge would yield a negative result.

questions.text: Two days after delivery, a newborn is brought to the clinic because of a red, irritated eye with yellow discharge. The mother had an unmedicated vaginal delivery at home; the patient did not receive any routine postpartum medications. Ophthalmic examination shows eyelid edema, conjunctival injection, and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge from the right eye. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?

choices.text: Oral erythromycin administered to the infant
IV ceftriaxone administered to the infant
Topical erythromycin administered to the infant
Oral doxycycline administered to the mother
Oral amoxicillin administered to the mother

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral erythromycin is the first-line treatment for chlamydial neonatal conjunctivitis, which typically occurs 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with mild eyelid swelling and watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge. This patient's presentation is consistent with NGC, for which oral erythromycin is not indicated as either prophylaxis or treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous or intramuscular ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice in infants with NGC. However, ceftriaxone is not used for NGC prophylaxis.

C) CORRECT:

Topical erythromycin ointment should be applied within 1 hour of birth to prevent NGC. In most states in the US, prophylaxis against NGC is required by law. If left untreated, NGC may result in corneal scarring and blindness. After confirming NGC (using culture and Gram stain or PCR), systemic treatment with either an IV or IM third-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone) is indicated. In addition, the eyes should be flushed with saline until the discharge clears.
Image Description:

The eyelids are swollen, with purulent exudate forming crusts around them. Below the crusts there may be a large reservoir of pus. Special care should be taken and safety goggles should be worn when examining the eyes.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline may be administered to treat mothers of newborns who have newborn conjunctivitis due to an infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. However, administration of oral doxycycline (as a prophylactic measure) in pregnant women is contraindicated because it may lead to bone damage and deposits in teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) in the offspring.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin can be used to treat infection with Chlamydia trachomatis in pregnant women and, therefore, help prevent chlamydial neonatal conjunctivitis (CNC). However, CNC typically occurs 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with mild eyelid swelling and watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge. This patient's presentation is more consistent with NGC. Amoxicillin is not the first-line treatment for infection with Neisseria gonorrhea and, therefore, would have not prevented this newborn's NGC.
questions.hint: This patient presents with conjunctival injection and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge 2 days after birth, all of which are consistent with neonatal gonococcal conjunctivitis (NGC). NGC is typically caused by ophthalmic colonization of the newborn's conjunctiva during delivery from mothers with Neisseria gonorrhea infection.

questions.text: You are seeing a 7-year-old boy in the emergency department who has a 2-day history of photophobia and pruritus around the right eye. This morning, his caregiver noticed crusts over the eyelashes of the right eye. He has a history of asthma and atopic dermatitis, and his medications include inhaled steroids and salbutamol. His immunizations are up-to-date. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there is conjunctival injection and redness of the right eye with watery discharge. Multiple vesicles with an erythematous base are present on the upper and lower eyelids. Visual acuity is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) can cause nonpurulent conjunctivitis, which manifests with photophobia, pruritus on the periocular area, crusts over the eyelashes, conjunctival injection, redness, and watery discharge from the eye. HSV-1 conjunctivitis is more common in children and adults, while HSV-2 often affects neonates. HSV conjunctivitis is usually unilateral and often manifests with a vesicular rash and corneal involvement (e.g., dendritic keratitis). Additionally, patients with a history of atopic dermatitis are particularly susceptible to HSV conjunctivitis.

HSV conjunctivitis is usually self-limited and resolves within 2 weeks, although neonatal forms can be fatal. The gold standard for diagnosis of HSV conjunctivitis is cell culture. However, typical cases in neonates or immunosuppressed patients should be treated without laboratory confirmation, as testing may delay treatment. In adults, treatment is only indicated in corneal involvement. Therapy usually consists of topical, oral, and/or IV acyclovir, depending on the severity of the disease, the age of the patient, and underlying conditions (e.g., immunosuppression).

Key learning point: Herpes simplex virus conjunctivitis often presents as unilateral, nonpurulent conjunctivitis with periocular vesicles, especially in children with atopic dermatitis.
Image Description:

Left eye

The conjunctival blood vessels are dilated (injection). There is no purulent discharge.

This finding is consistent with viral conjunctivitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Adenoviruses are the most common cause of viral (nonpurulent) conjunctivitis. The disease is highly contagious and commonly occurs in small outbreaks. Typical symptoms include itching, serous discharge, severe foreign body sensation, and conjunctival hyperemia, as mentioned in this case. However, adenovirus conjunctivitis typically affects both eyes, either simultaneously or in sequence. Most importantly, although it often presents with signs of systemic infection, such as pharyngitis, fever, and lymphadenopathy, it is not associated with a vesicular rash.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute infection with varicella-zoster virus sometimes causes conjunctivitis. Patients are usually children and present with additional symptoms such as fever and a generalized vesiculopustular rash. The conjunctiva can also be affected in reactivation of the latent virus in the trigeminal ganglion (herpes zoster ophthalmicus). These patients are often older or immunosuppressed and present with a headache, fever, and a vesicular rash along the trigeminal dermatome. None of these features are present in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Allergic conjunctivitis manifests with itchiness, chemosis (swelling of the conjunctiva), and serous secretion. Despite its association with atopic conditions such as asthma and atopic dermatitis, symptoms of allergic conjunctivitis are usually milder than those of infectious conjunctivitis and do not include a vesicular rash.

E) INCORRECT:

Bacterial conjunctivitis is the most common form of infectious conjunctivitis in children. Common pathogens include Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis. Infection usually manifests as purulent conjunctivitis with thick yellow, white, or green discharge, which is inconsistent with this patient's nonpurulent conjunctivitis and watery discharge.
questions.hint: What infection associated with multiple vesicles are patients with atopic dermatitis prone to?

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to your clinic with a 2-day history of red, itchy, tearing eyes. He reports no pain and his vision is clear. He recently spent a few days at his cousin's house in the countryside. On examination, there is bilateral conjunctival injection with watery discharge, chemosis, and bilateral eyelid edema. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Allergic conjunctivitis (AC) typically manifests with bilateral ocular itching, redness, and scant watery discharge, most commonly in young adults. AC is a hypersensitivity reaction against specific allergens (e.g., cat dander, pollen), to which this patient was likely exposed to in the countryside. Examination findings include diffuse conjunctival injection, chemosis, and eyelid edema. Additionally, eversion of the eyelid may show conjunctival papillae. Management of AC includes allergen avoidance, cold compresses, artificial tears, and topical pharmacotherapy (e.g., antihistamines). Systemic pharmacotherapy can be considered if nonocular symptoms are present.

See “Overview of conjunctivitis subtypes in children and adults” table.

Key learning point: Allergic conjunctivitis presents with bilateral itchy, red eyes, watery discharge, chemosis, and eyelid edema, often triggered by environmental allergens.
Image Description:

Right eye of an older adult

Conjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.

This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Bacterial conjunctivitis typically manifests with unilateral or bilateral diffuse conjunctival injection and thick, purulent discharge. Patients don't typically present with significant itching. Additionally, patients often present with significant eyelid erythema and pain, none of which is seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Viral conjunctivitis typically manifests with conjunctival injection and watery discharge. However, patients are unlikely to present with significant itching or eyelid edema. Although viral conjunctivitis can affect both eyes, it usually begins unilaterally. Additionally, patients often present with systemic and/or nasopharyngeal signs of viral infection (e.g., lymphadenopathy, pharyngitis).

D) INCORRECT:

Exacerbations of blepharitis can cause acute-onset bilateral eyelid swelling, itchiness, and tearing. However, blepharitis primarily manifests with erythema or adherent material (e.g., collarettes, crusty scaly plaques) at the lid margins. The absence of these findings and the presence of conjunctival injection and chemosis make a different diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS) can cause bilateral conjunctival injection. However, KCS does not affect the eyelids and is a subacute or chronic condition, not an acute one. Moreover, KCS typically results in dry eyes (rather than excessive tearing) and blurred vision (due to corneal involvement).
questions.hint: Individuals with this condition often have concomitant rhinitis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-day history of redness, foreign body sensation, and discharge in both eyes. She reports that her eyes feel “stuck together” and develop yellow crusts every morning. On ophthalmic examination, there is edema of both eyelids, bilateral conjunctival injection, and a thin purulent discharge. Which one of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisolone acetate drops) may be used for the treatment of refractory allergic conjunctivitis (e.g., vernal keratoconjunctivitis), which manifests with bilateral redness, foreign body sensation, and discharge of eyes, as seen in this patient. However, the discharge in this patient is purulent instead of watery/mucoid, and itching and follicles on the tarsal conjunctiva, both characteristic features of allergic conjunctivitis, are not seen in this patient.

Topical glucocorticoids should not be used for conjunctivitis unless an infectious etiology is ruled out, as they can lead to worsening of the infection and sight-threatening complications such as keratitis and corneal perforation.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical fluoroquinolones like ciprofloxacin are usually not preferred for empiric treatment of bacterial conjunctivitis because of the concerns surrounding increasing bacterial drug resistance. The only exception is contact lens wearers since the most common causative organism of bacterial conjunctivitis in this group of patients is Pseudomonas aeruginosa, against which fluoroquinolones are effective. Pseudomonas conjunctivitis is often more fulminant and can rapidly lead to sight-threatening keratitis and corneal perforation. As this patient does not wear contact lenses and her presentation is not as severe, another treatment option is more appropriate.

C) CORRECT:

The most common organism causing bacterial conjunctivitis in adults is Staphylococcus aureus, followed by Streptococcal pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae. While most cases of bacterial conjunctivitis are self-limited, the use of topical antibiotics speeds up recovery and may reduce the risk of transmission. There is no superior antibiotic regimen and selection should be based on cost, availability, and local resistance data. Empiric treatment should be with a topical broad-spectrum antibiotic, such as erythromycin or a combination of trimethoprim/polymyxin B.

Key learning point: Empiric treatment of acute bacterial conjunctivitis in adults is with a topical broad-spectrum antibiotic such as erythromycin to speed recovery and reduce transmission.
Image Description:

Left eye

There is massive conjunctival injection (hyperemia) and purulent discharge, especially visible in the medial corner of the eye and the margin of the lower lid.

This is the characteristic appearance of bacterial conjunctivitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical ketorolac, an NSAID, is used to reduce the pain, inflammation, and swelling seen in allergic conjunctivitis, which manifests with bilateral redness, foreign body sensation, and discharge of eyes, as seen in this patient. However, the discharge in this patient is purulent instead of watery/mucoid; and itching and follicles on the tarsal conjunctiva, both characteristic features of allergic conjunctivitis, are not seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Artificial tears (e.g., carboxymethyl cellulose) can be used for lubrication in patients with dry eye disease (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) as well as in contact lens wearers. Dry eye disease manifests with a foreign body sensation in the eye, along with itching and redness, but it is not accompanied by purulent discharge. While artificial tears may be used in bacterial conjunctivitis for symptomatic relief, a different treatment is required to target this patient's infection.
questions.hint: This patient's eyelid edema, conjunctival injection, and yellow purulent discharge are suggestive of acute bacterial conjunctivitis.

questions.text: A 15-day-old female newborn is brought to your clinic for evaluation of red eyes with discharge for 3 days. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother received irregular prenatal care during the third trimester. On examination, the newborn has watery discharge in both eyes and mild eyelid swelling. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus 2 is a common cause of viral conjunctivitis in neonates. It typically manifests within the first 14 days of life with nonpurulent, ocular discharge, corneal ulceration, and periocular vesicles. This patient lacks corneal ulceration and periocular vesicles, which make this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Silver nitrate exposure can lead to chemical conjunctivitis, which usually manifests in the 1st day of life with mild watery discharge and conjunctival injections. Discharge and eyelid swelling was observed in this patient 12 days after delivery, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of bacterial conjunctivitis in adults and typically presents with unilateral conjunctival injection, chemosis, and thick purulent discharge. This patient has watery eye discharge. Moreover, Staphylococcus aureus is not a common cause of conjunctivitis in neonates.

D) INCORRECT:

Gonococcal conjunctivitis, which is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, typically manifests 2–7 days after delivery with profuse, purulent, ocular discharge in addition to a pronounced eyelid swelling. This patient, meanwhile, has a mild eyelid swelling and watery discharge observed 12 days after delivery, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

Chlamydial conjunctivitis, which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, typically manifests at 5–14 days after birth with watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge in addition to mild eyelid swelling, as seen in this patient. Oral erythromycin is the treatment for chlamydial conjunctivitis.

Key learning point: Chlamydial conjunctivitis in newborns typically presents 5–14 days after birth with watery or mucopurulent discharge and mild eyelid swelling, and is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.
questions.hint: A gram stain of this patient's discharge would yield a negative result.

questions.text: Two days after delivery, a newborn is brought to your clinic with a red, irritated right eye and yellow discharge. The mother had an unmedicated vaginal delivery at home, and the newborn did not receive any routine postpartum medications. On ophthalmic examination, there is eyelid edema, conjunctival injection, and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge from the right eye. Which one of the following is most likely to have prevented this condition?

choices.text: Oral erythromycin administered to the newborn.
Topical ocular gentamicin administered to the newborn.
Intramuscular ceftriaxone administered to the mother.
Topical intravaginal silver nitrate administered to the mother.
Oral doxycycline administered to the mother.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral erythromycin is the first-line treatment for chlamydial neonatal conjunctivitis, which typically occurs 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with mild eyelid swelling and watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge. This patient’s presentation is consistent with NGC, for which oral erythromycin is no longer recommended for prevention or treatment. Although it was once used prophylactically, its use was discontinued after links to hypertrophic pyloric stenosis emerged.

B) INCORRECT:

Because of its high risk of chemical conjunctivitis, the Canadian Paediatric Society advises against using gentamicin ointment or povidone‑iodine for neonatal conjunctivitis prophylaxis. In provinces or territories that still mandate ocular prophylaxis, erythromycin ointment should be used.

C) CORRECT:

All pregnant individuals in Canada should be screened for gonorrhea at their first prenatal visit in the first trimester and again in the third trimester. For the prevention of neonatal gonococcal and chlamydial NGC, the emphasis has shifted from routine universal ocular prophylaxis to maternal screening and treatment. If a mother tests positive for gonorrhea, IM or IV ceftriaxone is administered to treat the infection and prevent neonatal transmission. The Canadian Pediatric Society advises against routine neonatal ocular topical prophylaxis due to increasing antibiotic resistance and the risk of chemical conjunctivitis from certain agents (e.g., silver nitrate, gentamicin, povidone-iodine). However, in some provinces where universal ocular prophylaxis is still legally mandated, erythromycin ointment should be used.

Untreated NGC can cause corneal scarring and blindness. This newborn with gonococcal NGC requires a single IM or IV dose of a third-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone, cefotaxime). If the mother was not screened during pregnancy but tests positive for gonorrhea postpartum, the newborn should have a conjunctival culture for N. gonorrhoeae and receive a single empirical dose of a third-generation cephalosporin even if the newborn is asymptomatic. If postpartum chlamydia testing is positive, a wait-and-watch approach is preferred over routine ocular culture and empirical treatment for asymptomatic newborns.

Key learning point: Infectious neonatal conjunctivitis is best prevented through routine prenatal screening and adequate maternal treatment.
Image Description:

The eyelids are swollen, with purulent exudate forming crusts around them. Below the crusts there may be a large reservoir of pus. Special care should be taken and safety goggles should be worn when examining the eyes.

D) INCORRECT:

Maternal genital infection is the primary risk factor for infectious neonatal conjunctivitis, but no clinical trial has shown that intrapartum vaginal silver nitrate prevents infectious NGC. Although used prophylactically in the past, ocular silver nitrate causes a high rate of chemical conjunctivitis and is no longer recommended for routine administration in neonates.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline may be administered to treat mothers of newborns who have newborn conjunctivitis due to an infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. However, administration of oral doxycArticles (27)ycline (as a prophylactic measure) in pregnant women is contraindicated because it may lead to bone damage and deposits in teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) in the offspring.
questions.hint: This patient presents with conjunctival injection and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge 2 days after birth, all of which are consistent with neonatal gonococcal conjunctivitis (NGC). NGC is typically caused by ophthalmic colonization of the newborn's conjunctiva during delivery from mothers with Neisseria gonorrhea infection.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a 4-day history of bilateral red eyes and clear discharge. She reports severe itching and burning sensation, with difficulty concentrating at work due to the discomfort. She mentions that her symptoms worsen when she works outside as a landscape designer. She has tried allergen avoidance, artificial tears, and cold compresses without relief.  On examination, there is conjunctival injection, chemosis, and some crust formation around both eyes. Her visual acuity is normal, and she denies photophobia or eye pain. Which management approach is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Persistent, bilateral pruritic conjunctivitis with clear discharge and environmental triggers despite supportive measures is most consistent with allergic conjunctivitis requiring pharmacologic therapy. A topical antihistamine and mast-cell stabilizer such as ketotifen directly targets itching and hyperemia and is the appropriate escalation after supportive care has failed. This approach addresses symptoms rapidly and avoids unnecessary antibiotics.

B) INCORRECT:

Supportive care alone is appropriate for viral conjunctivitis, which typically starts unilaterally and gradually affects the other eye with clear watery discharge. The prominent itching and environmental triggers make allergic conjunctivitis more likely, requiring specific treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral azithromycin is the treatment of choice for trachoma caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. This patient's acute presentation with clear discharge and environmental triggers is not consistent with chronic trachoma infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics like erythromycin are indicated for bacterial conjunctivitis, which typically presents with thick mucopurulent discharge and difficulty opening eyes in the morning. The clear discharge and prominent itching in this case are not consistent with bacterial etiology.

E) INCORRECT:

Saline lavage is used as an adjunct treatment for gonococcal conjunctivitis, which presents as hyperacute conjunctivitis with marked eye swelling and profuse purulent discharge. This patient's clear discharge and lack of purulent features make gonococcal conjunctivitis unlikely.
